content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Angel Gonzalez: Well, I was born in Miami, Florida, and I've lived here my whole life. Growing up, my parents both had Bachelor's degrees, so they always encouraged me to value education. We lived in a modest house on the South Atlantic coast, and I remember my childhood being pretty typical—playing with friends, going to school, and helping out around the house when I could. My mom was a stay-at-home mom, and my dad worked in construction. We weren't rich, but we had everything we needed. I was always a good student, but I didn't have a clear path after high school. I ended up working part-time at a local store while I figured things out, and I'm still trying to decide what I want to do next. I'm Catholic, and that's been a big part of my life—going to church every Sunday and celebrating traditions with my family. I speak Spanish at home, which I'm proud of, even though I don't use it as much as I'd like. Life hasn't been too dramatic, but I'm grateful for the stability I've had and the support of my family.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Angel Gonzalez: Hmm, thinking about it, there was a moment that felt like a crossroads. I was about 18, right after I graduated high school. I had a few options: I could go to college, but I wasn't sure what I wanted to study, and I didn't want to take on student debt. I could also try to get a full-time job, but I wasn't ready to commit to that either. I remember talking to my dad one night after he came home from work. He told me, 'Angel, life is like a construction site—sometimes you have to lay the foundation before you can build something real.' That stuck with me. I decided to take a gap year, work part-time, and explore my interests. I started volunteering at a community center, which opened my eyes to the importance of helping others. That experience made me realize I wanted to pursue something in social work or community development. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the right one for me. I feel like that moment shaped who I am today—more grounded, more aware of the world around me, and more determined to make a difference in my own way.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Angel Gonzalez: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made all at once. It felt more like a series of small decisions that added up. After that conversation with my dad, I started reflecting more on what I wanted my life to look like. I didn't want to just follow someone else's path, but I also didn't want to be aimless. So I made a plan to work part-time, save some money, and take some online courses to see what interested me. That was a conscious step. Then, when I volunteered at the community center, I realized how much I enjoyed helping others, and that was another decision—choosing to pursue that path instead of something more traditional. I think it was a mix of intention and experience. I made the choice, but the experience shaped how I understood that choice.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Angel Gonzalez: Absolutely, I think having someone or an organization that could offer guidance would have made a big difference. When I was trying to figure out my next step after high school, I didn't really know where to start. I remember talking to a teacher at my high school, Mrs. Delgado, who noticed I was struggling with direction. She suggested I look into some local community programs and even connected me with a mentor who had worked in social services. That mentor, Mr. Ramirez, became a real influence on me. He shared his own story of starting out in a similar place and helped me see that it was okay not to have everything figured out right away. I wish I had reached out more to people like that earlier. Sometimes, we think we have to figure things out on our own, but having someone who believes in you and can offer perspective can make all the difference.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Angel Gonzalez: Right now, I'm single and don't have any children. My family is still very important to me, especially my parents. They've been my biggest supporters throughout my life, and I still live with them in the same house on Elm Street where I grew up. My mom, she's always been the heart of our family—she cooks all our meals, keeps the house running, and makes sure we're all on the same page. My dad, he's the kind of person who works hard and doesn't complain, even when things get tough. I see a lot of myself in him, especially his work ethic. I don't have a partner right now because I've been focused on figuring out my path and making sure I'm ready for a serious relationship. I want someone who shares my values, who's kind, and who's also looking for something meaningful in life. I think I'm getting there, but for now, I'm content with where I am and the support of my family.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people around me and the small choices I've made along the way. It's interesting to look back and see how my childhood, my family's values, and even a conversation with my dad became turning points that led me to where I am today. I never thought of myself as someone with a dramatic story, but when I break it down, there were moments that mattered—like deciding to take that gap year, volunteering at the community center, and letting my family's support guide me. I also realized how much I owe to people like Mrs. Delgado and Mr. Ramirez, who saw potential in me when I didn't see it myself. It's comforting to know that even if life hasn't been filled with grand adventures, it's been built on steady foundations and meaningful connections. I'm still figuring things out, but I feel more grounded now than ever before.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Angel Gonzalez: My sister, Maria, is someone I haven't mentioned yet. She's two years older than me, and she's always been the more driven one in our family. She went to college right after high school and became a teacher in a local middle school. She's been married for a few years now and has a daughter, Sofia, who's about five. I admire her a lot—she's the one who always pushes me to think bigger and not be afraid of challenges. We don't talk as often as I'd like because she's so busy with work and family, but whenever we do, it's always meaningful. She's the one who encouraged me to take that gap year and actually helped me find some of the online courses I took. I feel lucky to have her in my life, even if we're not as close as I wish we were. She's my role model in many ways, and I hope to be half as inspiring to my own kids someday, if I ever have them.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Angel Gonzalez: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me. One of them is Luis, who I've known since high school. We used to hang out all the time, play sports, and even started a small music project together. He's the kind of person who always knows how to make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. After I took that gap year, he actually encouraged me to keep going with the volunteer work and even helped me set up a small fundraiser for the community center. He's more of a free spirit than I am, but I respect his passion and creativity. Then there's Jasmine, who I met through the community center. She's a few years older than me and works as a social worker. She's been a great mentor and friend—someone I can talk to when I'm unsure about my path. She's the one who really helped me understand what social work is all about and why it matters. I don't have a huge circle of friends, but the ones I do have have been there for me in meaningful ways. They've helped me grow, and I'm grateful for them.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Angel Gonzalez: I live in a neighborhood on the east side of Miami, just a few blocks away from the community center where I volunteer. It's a pretty diverse area—there are a lot of families, some older homes, and a few small businesses that have been around for years. The vibe is friendly and laid-back, but there's also a strong sense of community. People know each other, and there's always someone willing to lend a hand if you need it. I like that about it—it feels like a place where everyone has a story, and you can always find something to learn from someone else. The streets are quiet in the mornings, and there's a nice park nearby where I like to take walks when I need to clear my head. It's not the most glamorous part of the city, but it's home, and I feel connected to it in a way that I can't explain. I think that's why I want to work in community development someday—because I want to help make places like this even better for the people who live here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Angel Gonzalez: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not the kind of place where you have to lock your doors at night or worry about strangers lurking around, but I also know that no neighborhood is completely without its challenges. There are some areas nearby where things can get rough, but I've never felt threatened in my own part of the city. The sense of community here helps a lot—people look out for each other. I remember one time when I was walking home late from the community center, and a neighbor saw me and offered to walk with me. That kind of thing happens more often than I think people realize. I think safety is about more than just the absence of danger—it's about feeling connected to the people around you, knowing that if something goes wrong, someone will be there to help. That's something I really value, and I think it's one of the reasons I want to work in community development. I want to help make sure that everyone in this neighborhood feels safe and supported, just like I do.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Angel Gonzalez: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The good thing is, I've always felt a sense of belonging here. There's a rhythm to life in this neighborhood that I've come to appreciate—the way people greet each other on the street, the way the local shops know your name, the way the park feels like an extension of home. But it's not without its challenges. Sometimes, I feel like I'm stuck in a cycle of part-time work and trying to figure out my future, and it can be frustrating. I know my parents are proud of me, but I also want to prove to myself that I can do more than just get by. There are days when I feel like I'm not making enough progress, and I wonder if I'm going to be one of those people who never really 'make it.' But then I remember the people I've met here—the ones who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself, like Mrs. Delgado, Mr. Ramirez, and even my sister Maria. They remind me that growth isn't always about big, dramatic moments. It's about showing up every day, even when it's hard, and keeping the faith that things will work out in their own time.

Going through the interview questions about my family, friends, and neighborhood made me realize how much my sense of identity is tied to the people and places I know best. Talking about my parents, my sister, and the friends who've supported me over the years reminded me of how important it is to have a strong support system, especially when you're trying to figure out your path in life. It also made me reflect on how much I value the sense of community in my neighborhood—it's not just a place to live, but a place where I feel connected and safe. I think that's why I'm drawn to the idea of working in community development; I want to help create spaces where people feel like they belong, just like I do here. It's comforting to know that even if my life hasn't been filled with grand adventures, it's been built on steady foundations and meaningful relationships.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Angel Gonzalez: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there are definitely some variations depending on what I'm working on. I start most mornings around 7 or 8, depending on how I feel. I usually have breakfast with my parents, and we talk about the day ahead. My mom always makes something simple but comforting—like eggs and toast or maybe some arepas if she's feeling adventurous. I work part-time at a local grocery store, so I'm usually on the clock from 9 to 12, and then I have some free time in the afternoon. On days when I'm volunteering at the community center, I'll head there after work, which usually means I'm there until around 3 or 4. I try to take a walk in the park after that to clear my head, especially if I've been thinking a lot about my future or something I'm working on. On weekends, I like to spend time with my sister if she's around, or hang out with Luis and some of the other guys from high school. We'll go to a coffee shop, play some basketball, or just talk about life. It's not the most exciting schedule, but it's steady, and I like that. There's something comforting about knowing what to expect, even if I'm still figuring out what I want to do with my life.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Angel Gonzalez: I work part-time at a local grocery store, mostly in the mornings from 9 to 12, Monday through Friday. It's not a glamorous job, but it's steady, and I appreciate the flexibility it gives me. I get to interact with a lot of regular customers, some of whom I've known for years. It's interesting how people come in with their own stories—some are just picking up groceries, others are there to catch up with someone or just to have a moment of quiet. I've learned a lot from watching how people handle their lives, even in small ways. I also do some odd jobs on the side, like helping out with deliveries or fixing things around the neighborhood when I can. It's not much, but it helps me save a little and gives me a sense of purpose. I know I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm learning that every job, no matter how small, can be a step toward something bigger.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Angel Gonzalez: Outside of work and volunteering, I also have a few personal routines that keep me grounded. I try to read a little every night, usually something non-fiction—like books on social issues or personal development. I find that it helps me think more clearly about the kind of work I want to do in the future. I also have a habit of writing in a journal, mostly just to process my thoughts or jot down ideas that come to me. It's not anything formal, just a way to stay connected with myself. On weekends, if I'm not with my sister or friends, I like to spend some time helping out around the house or just sitting on the porch and watching the neighborhood come to life. There's something peaceful about seeing the same faces, hearing the same sounds, and knowing that I'm part of something bigger than myself. It might not sound like much, but these little things add up and help me feel like I'm living a full life, even if I'm still figuring out what that life looks like in the long run.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Angel Gonzalez: Well, lately, I've been trying to get more involved in the community center beyond just volunteering. I started helping out with organizing events and even assisting with some of the outreach programs. It's been a bit of a shift for me, moving from just showing up to actually taking on more responsibility. I've also started taking online courses in social work, which has been challenging but rewarding. I used to think I needed to have everything figured out before I could commit to something, but now I'm realizing that growth happens in the doing. I've also been trying to speak Spanish more at home, even though my parents are pretty comfortable with English now. It's been a way for me to reconnect with my roots and keep that part of my identity alive. I know it's small stuff, but these changes are helping me feel more connected to who I want to become.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Angel Gonzalez: I don't have children yet, but I like to imagine what a typical day might look like for them if I did. I think I'd want them to have a balanced routine—starting with a good breakfast, maybe some time to read or play before heading to school. I'd hope they'd be involved in after-school activities, like sports or music, something that helps them develop both physically and creatively. I'd also want them to have time to volunteer or help others, just like I did, because I believe that giving back is an important part of growing up. Of course, I'd also want them to have time to just be kids, to play with friends and explore their interests without too much pressure. I know I'm still figuring out my own path, but if I ever have kids, I want them to feel supported, loved, and encouraged to be the best version of themselves—just like I hope I've been in my own life.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my identity is shaped by the people and places I know best. Talking about my family, friends, and neighborhood reminded me of how important it is to have a strong support system, especially when you're trying to figure out your path in life. It also made me think about the rhythm of my daily life—how even though I'm still figuring things out, there's a certain comfort in the consistency of my routine. I realized that growth isn't always about big, dramatic moments, but about showing up every day, even when it's hard, and keeping the faith that things will work out in their own time. I'm grateful for the people who've supported me along the way, and I hope to one day be able to give back to my community in the same way they've helped me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Angel Gonzalez: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty average. I don't have any major medical issues, but I've been trying to be more mindful of my habits lately. I used to eat a lot of fast food when I was working long hours, but I've been making an effort to cook more at home, especially with my mom's help. She's always been the one to keep us on track with healthy meals—lots of rice, beans, and grilled fish, which are staples in our household. I also try to stay active, even if it's just walking in the park or playing basketball with Luis on the weekends. I've been meaning to start going to the gym more regularly, but between work, volunteering, and my online classes, it's been tough to find the time. I do make sure to get enough sleep, though—usually around seven or eight hours a night. I think my mental health is just as important as my physical health, so I try to stay positive and take things one day at a time. I've been journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and keep stress at bay. Overall, I feel pretty good, but I know there's always room for improvement.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Angel Gonzalez: What makes it easy to stay healthy, I think, is having a routine and the support of my family. My mom always makes sure we eat well, and she's the one who keeps me on track with meals and reminds me to take breaks when I'm working too much. The hardest part, though, is finding the time to take care of myself when life gets busy. I know I should be going to the gym more, but between work, volunteering, and my online classes, it's easy to put it off. I also struggle with stress sometimes, especially when I'm trying to figure out my future. But I've been learning that small things—like walking in the park, eating home-cooked meals, and even just taking a few minutes to breathe—can make a big difference. It's not about being perfect, but about showing up for myself, even on the days when I don't feel like it.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Angel Gonzalez: In the past two years, I haven't had any major health issues, but there was a time when I was dealing with some pretty intense stress and anxiety. It started around the time I began taking those online courses and taking on more responsibilities at the community center. I was juggling work, school, volunteering, and trying to figure out my future all at once, and it got to the point where I was constantly tired, had trouble sleeping, and felt like I wasn't making progress. I didn't realize how much it was affecting me until one of my friends, Jasmine, noticed and actually sat down with me to talk about it. She encouraged me to start journaling more and to take small breaks throughout the day to breathe and reset. That helped a lot. I also started going to a local support group for people who are trying to make changes in their lives, and that was really helpful. It wasn't a medical diagnosis or anything like that, but it was a wake-up call that I needed to take my mental health more seriously. I've been working on it ever since, and I feel like I'm in a better place now—more balanced, more aware of my limits, and more willing to ask for help when I need it.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Angel Gonzalez: Honestly, I haven't had any health issues that have really disrupted my ability to work or take care of myself, but there were definitely times when the stress got to me. I remember one point where I was so overwhelmed with everything—work, volunteering, school, and trying to figure out my future—that I started skipping meals and not sleeping well. It wasn't anything serious, but it affected my focus and energy. I think what made it harder was that I didn't want to admit I was struggling. I felt like I should be able to handle it on my own, but in the end, it was my friends and family who helped me realize I didn't have to go through it alone. Now, I'm more aware of how important it is to take care of myself, both physically and mentally. I've learned that if I don't take care of my health, it's harder to do the things I want to do—like helping others or working toward my goals. So I try to be more intentional about it now, even if it's just small steps like eating better, getting enough rest, or taking a few minutes to breathe when I feel overwhelmed.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Angel Gonzalez: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—mostly steady, but with moments of uncertainty. I've been working harder to balance everything, and while it's not always easy, I feel like I'm making progress. I've been more committed to my online courses, and even though it's challenging, I'm starting to see how they connect to the work I want to do. Volunteering at the community center has become more than just a way to pass the time—it's become a part of who I am. I've started to feel more confident in myself, more sure of the path I want to take, even if it's still a little unclear. I've also been trying to be more present in my daily life, whether it's helping my mom with dinner, walking with Luis, or just sitting on the porch and watching the neighborhood. I think I'm learning to appreciate the little things more, and that's been a big shift for me. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I feel like I'm moving forward, and that's something to be grateful for.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily life and health are intertwined with the people and routines I've built over time. It's interesting to look back at how my recent changes—like getting more involved at the community center, taking online courses, and speaking Spanish more at home—have helped me feel more connected to who I want to become. At the same time, it reminded me how important it is to take care of my health, both physically and mentally. I used to think I could handle everything on my own, but now I see that growth happens when I allow myself to be supported, whether it's through family, friends, or even small habits like eating better or getting enough rest. I'm still figuring things out, but I feel more balanced and more aware of the little steps that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Angel Gonzalez: I think I've struggled with anxiety at times, especially when I'm trying to balance so many things at once. There were moments last year when I felt like I was running in place, working hard but not really moving forward. I used to push through it, thinking that if I just kept going, it would all work out. But I've learned that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and it's even better to acknowledge it instead of ignoring it. I've started talking to Jasmine more about it, and she's helped me understand that anxiety isn't something to be ashamed of—it's just another part of life that you have to learn how to manage. I've also started practicing mindfulness, even if it's just taking a few deep breaths when I feel my thoughts spiraling. It's not a cure-all, but it's given me a tool to use when I need it most. I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and not let the pressure of figuring everything out define how I feel about myself.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Angel Gonzalez: For my family, it's been a mix of pride, support, and quiet concern. My parents have always been there for me, but I can tell they worry about my future sometimes. They see how hard I'm working, how I'm trying to balance everything, and they want the best for me. My mom, she's always been the one to remind me that I don't have to have everything figured out right away. She tells me stories about her own life, how she didn't know what she wanted to do when she was my age, but she kept going and found her way. My dad, he's more quiet about it, but I know he's proud of me. He always says, 'You're doing the right thing, Angel,' even when I'm not sure if I am. My sister, Maria, she's been the most vocal about it. She's always pushing me to take the next step, to commit to something, to not be afraid of the unknown. I know she wants the best for me, but sometimes I feel like she's impatient with me. Still, I'm grateful for all of them. They've been my foundation, and I know that no matter where I go or what I do, they'll always have my back.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Angel Gonzalez: For me, religion has always been a source of comfort and strength, especially growing up in a Catholic household. My parents made sure that faith was a part of our daily lives—attending Mass every Sunday, celebrating holidays with family, and even saying prayers before meals. It wasn't just about following traditions; it was about feeling connected to something bigger than myself. I remember sitting in church as a kid, listening to the priest talk about kindness and forgiveness, and thinking how those values shaped the way my parents treated others. Even now, I find myself turning to faith when things feel uncertain. It's not about having all the answers, but about knowing that there's a sense of purpose and community in what I believe. I don't go to church as often as I used to, but I still find solace in the rituals and the lessons I learned growing up. I think that's why I'm drawn to helping others—it feels like a way to live out the values I was taught, even if I'm not always sure how to put them into practice.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Angel Gonzalez: To be honest, I don't use social media that much. I have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family and old friends, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or posting updates. I think it's more of a passive thing for me—checking in every now and then to see what's going on with my sister, my cousins, or even some of the teachers from high school. I used to be more active on Instagram when I was in college, but that was a few years ago. Now, I find myself more connected to the people around me in real life, whether it's through the community center, my work, or just hanging out with Luis or Jasmine. I guess I'm not opposed to social media, but I don't feel the need to be constantly online. There's something about being present in the moment, even if it's just talking to someone face-to-face, that feels more meaningful to me. Plus, I don't want to get caught up in comparing my life to others' highlight reels. I'm content with my own pace, and I think that's something I've learned from my family and the people who've supported me along the way.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Angel Gonzalez: Honestly, I don't think I've relied much on social media for support during tough times. I know some people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, but for me, it's always been the people I know in real life who have helped me the most. When I was going through that stressful period with work, school, and volunteering, it was my mom who reminded me to take things one step at a time, and it was Jasmine who actually sat down with me and listened when I didn't know how to explain what I was feeling. I think I've always preferred face-to-face connections over virtual ones. That said, I do appreciate being able to check in with family or old friends through Facebook, especially when I'm feeling down and just need to see that someone is thinking of me. It's not the same as being there in person, but it's still a small comfort. I guess I'm just not the type to open up to a lot of strangers online. I feel like the support I need is already here, in my neighborhood, with the people I've come to trust over the years.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my mental health and well-being have been shaped by the challenges I've faced and the support I've received along the way. It's been a year of learning to balance work, school, volunteering, and my own sense of direction, and there were definitely times when I felt overwhelmed and unsure of where I was headed. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but now I see how important it is to acknowledge when I'm struggling and to lean on the people who care about me—whether it's my family, my friends, or even someone like Jasmine who took the time to listen. I've also started to understand that anxiety isn't something to be ashamed of, but rather something I can learn to manage with small, intentional steps—like taking deep breaths, journaling, or simply giving myself permission to rest when I need to. It's not always easy, but I'm starting to feel more in control of my thoughts and emotions, and that gives me hope for the future. I know I'm still figuring things out, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the people who've helped me along the way.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Angel Gonzalez: In the past few months, I've actually noticed that my stress levels have gone down a bit, which is a relief. I think it's because I've started to feel more in control of my time and my goals. I'm still juggling a lot, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most. When I feel overwhelmed, I've been using some of the coping strategies I've picked up over time—like taking a walk in the park, talking to Jasmine or my mom, or even just sitting quietly for a few minutes and breathing deeply. I've also started setting smaller, more manageable goals for myself, which helps me feel like I'm making progress instead of getting stuck in the same place. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that it's okay to take things one step at a time. I think the biggest change for me has been realizing that I don't have to have everything figured out right away. Just showing up and doing the best I can each day has been enough, and that's given me a sense of peace I didn't have before.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Angel Gonzalez: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. We live in a modest two-bedroom apartment on Elm Street, and the rent is about $800 a month. My parents split the costs, so I only pay around $300, which is manageable. Groceries are another big one—my mom does most of the cooking, and we stick to basics like rice, beans, vegetables, and some meat. We try to be careful with our spending, but sometimes we have to buy things on sale or from the local market to save money. Transportation is also a factor since I work at the grocery store and volunteer at the community center. I have an old car that I inherited from my uncle, and I pay for gas and maintenance out of my part-time earnings. I also set aside a little each month for savings, even if it's just $50 or so. It's not much, but it helps me feel like I'm working toward something. I know it's not the most comfortable life, but it's stable, and I'm grateful for that. I think the biggest challenge is making sure we don't overspend on things we don't really need, but my parents have always been good about keeping things in check. It's not easy, but I'm learning how to manage money better, and that's something I hope to carry with me no matter where life takes me.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Angel Gonzalez: Last month, our household spent around $1,800, which is pretty close to what we usually spend each month. The breakdown is pretty consistent—rent takes up the biggest chunk, as I mentioned, and then groceries, utilities, and transportation follow. We also have some smaller expenses like phone bills, internet, and occasional things like a movie night or a special meal when we feel like treating ourselves. I think the key for us is that we don't have a lot of debt or big surprises, which makes it easier to stick to a budget. My parents are really good about planning ahead, and I've been trying to learn from them. I know I'm not making a lot of money right now, but I feel like I'm getting better at managing what I have. It's not about luxury—it's about making sure we can cover the basics and still have a little something left over for the things that make life worth it, like family dinners or a weekend out with friends.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Angel Gonzalez: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment on Elm Street, the same place I've lived since I was a kid. My parents have always believed in staying in one place, even as things change around us. Renting has always been more practical for us—my dad worked in construction, and he knew that buying a house wasn't something we could commit to when we were starting out. Plus, with my sister moving out and starting her own family, it made sense for us to keep things simple. I like the stability of renting here, even though I know one day I might want to buy a place of my own. For now, though, this feels like home, and I'm grateful for the comfort and security it provides.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Angel Gonzalez: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, mostly depending on the season and what's going on in our household. In the summer, for example, we use a lot more electricity for air conditioning, and that bumps up our utility bill. We also tend to spend a bit more on groceries during the holidays, especially around Christmas and Easter, when we like to have bigger meals and maybe even treat ourselves to something special. On the other hand, during the winter, we don't use as much electricity, so our utility costs go down a bit. I also noticed that when I started taking online courses, I had to pay for some additional fees and materials, which added a small expense to my monthly budget. But overall, my parents are really good about keeping things in check. They track our spending closely, and we've learned to adjust our habits when needed—like buying in bulk or cutting back on non-essentials. It's not always easy, but I feel like we've found a rhythm that works for us, and that gives me a sense of security, even if we're not rolling in money.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and real-life connections have shaped my sense of well-being and support system. It's interesting to think about how my parents, especially my mom, have always been my emotional anchor, reminding me that it's okay not to have everything figured out. My sister, Maria, even though she's more driven and sometimes impatient, has been a source of motivation and guidance, pushing me to take the next step when I'm hesitant. I also realized how much I value face-to-face connections over virtual ones, even though I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family and old friends. I've learned that my mental health is deeply tied to the people around me, and I'm grateful for the support I've received from them. It's comforting to know that I don't have to rely on social media for emotional support, because the people I care about are already here, in my neighborhood, in my life.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Angel Gonzalez: I try to save in small, consistent ways, even if it's not a lot. I have a savings account, and I set aside whatever I can each month—usually around $50 to $75—after paying for rent, groceries, and other essentials. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of control and a little cushion for unexpected things. My parents also have their own savings, and they've always encouraged me to think about the future, even if I'm not there yet. I know I'm not saving for a house or anything big right now, but I want to build the habit. I also save in another way—by investing in myself, like taking those online courses or learning more Spanish. I think that's a form of saving too, because it's building something that can help me in the long run. It's not always easy, especially when money is tight, but I'm learning that even small steps can add up over time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Angel Gonzalez: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any big purchases, honestly. I know I'm not in a position to buy a house or even a car anytime soon, but I want to make sure I have some financial security just in case something unexpected happens. I've been trying to build that habit of setting aside even small amounts each month, and it's been helpful. I also save in another way—by investing in myself, like taking those online courses or learning more Spanish. I think that's a form of saving too, because it's building something that can help me in the long run. It's not always easy, especially when money is tight, but I'm learning that even small steps can add up over time.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Angel Gonzalez: My occupation right now is working part-time at a local grocery store, and I also volunteer at the community center. At the grocery store, my main duties are restocking shelves, helping customers find what they need, and keeping the aisles tidy. It's not glamorous work, but I take pride in making sure the store runs smoothly and that people can find what they're looking for. The most important part of my job, I think, is the interaction with the customers. Many of them are regulars, and I've come to know their names, their preferences, and even some of their stories. It's interesting how a simple conversation over a bag of chips or a loaf of bread can turn into a moment of connection. At the community center, my role has evolved a bit over the past year. I started as a volunteer, helping out with events and organizing supplies, but now I'm more involved in outreach programs and helping to coordinate activities for the kids and families in the neighborhood. The most important part of that work is seeing the impact it has on people—whether it's a child getting excited about a new book or a parent feeling more connected to the community. It's not always easy, and there are days when I feel like I'm not doing enough, but I know that every small act of service matters. I'm still figuring out what I want to do with my life, but I feel like these jobs are helping me build the skills and the heart I need to make a difference someday.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Angel Gonzalez: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours a week, depending on the season and how much I'm volunteering. At the grocery store, I'm on the clock from 9 to 12, Monday through Friday, which is 15 hours right there. Then, when I'm volunteering at the community center, I'll usually spend another 5 to 10 hours a week, depending on the events or programs we're running. There are weeks when I'm busier with outreach or organizing, and others when I'm just helping out with smaller tasks. I also have my online courses, which take up a few hours each week, so I have to be careful not to overcommit. It's a balance, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most. I know I'm not working full-time, but I'm okay with that for now. It gives me time to focus on my studies, help out in the community, and still be there for my family. I think that's what works for me right now—steady, manageable hours that let me keep moving forward without burning out.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Angel Gonzalez: Actually, I've only had one main job at the grocery store, but I do take on some side gigs here and there when I can. For example, I help out with local delivery services on weekends, especially during the busy season when people are ordering more online. I also do some handyman work for neighbors—fixing things around their houses, painting, or even helping with small repairs. It's not a lot, but it gives me a little extra income and keeps me busy. I think it's important to have a few different ways to earn money, especially when you're still figuring out your path. Plus, it gives me a sense of independence and helps me feel like I'm contributing in more ways than just my part-time job or volunteering. I know it's not the most stable income, but it works for me right now.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my daily life and emotional well-being are connected to the people and routines I've built over time. It's interesting to think about how my stress levels have decreased lately, not because everything has gotten easier, but because I've learned to prioritize what matters most. I've also come to appreciate the small ways I manage my emotions—whether it's taking a walk in the park, talking to my mom, or even just breathing deeply when I feel overwhelmed. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but now I see how important it is to lean on the people I trust, whether it's my family, my friends, or even the community around me. Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Angel Gonzalez: In total, our household made around $2,500 in the past month. That includes my part-time income from the grocery store, my parents' earnings from their jobs, and the small amount I make from my side gigs like deliveries and handyman work. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and a little extra for things like groceries, utilities, and even some savings. My parents have always been careful with money, and I've been learning from them how to budget and prioritize what's important. I know we're not wealthy, but I feel lucky to have a stable income and the support of my family. It's not about having everything, but about making sure we can cover the essentials and still have a little something left over for the things that make life worth it—like family dinners, helping others, or even just taking a weekend trip to the beach.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Angel Gonzalez: I've been working at the grocery store for about two years now, ever since I finished high school. It's been a steady job, and while it doesn't come with the typical benefits like health insurance or paid vacation time, it does offer some flexibility. I get to set my own schedule to a degree, which is important because I also volunteer at the community center and take online courses. The store does offer sick time, but it's not formalized like it is in some other jobs—I just let my manager know when I'm not feeling well, and she's usually understanding. I know it's not the most glamorous job, but I appreciate the stability it gives me. It also gives me a chance to interact with people from all walks of life, which I find really rewarding. I've learned a lot from the regulars, and sometimes they share stories or advice that stick with me. It's not much, but I feel like I'm doing something meaningful, even if it's just restocking shelves or helping someone find the right product.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Angel Gonzalez: My relationships at work are pretty good overall. My manager, Ms. Lopez, is someone I respect a lot. She's been with the store for years and knows how things run. She's fair, and even though she's strict about keeping the store organized, she's also understanding when things get busy or when I need to adjust my schedule for volunteering or school. I think she sees me as someone who's trying to do more than just show up, and that means a lot. As for my coworkers, we get along well. Some of them have been there for a long time, and they've been really helpful in teaching me the ropes. We don't talk about much more than work, but there's a sense of camaraderie—like when we're all working late or helping each other out during a rush. I don't have any close friends at work, but I feel like I'm part of a team, and that makes the job more bearable. I think the relationships are simple, but they're enough to make the work feel like something I can handle, even if it's not the most exciting place to be.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Angel Gonzalez: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's still some flexibility, which I really appreciate. I usually work the same hours every week—9 to 12 on Monday through Friday—and my manager is pretty consistent about that. But if something comes up, like a family event or a volunteer commitment, she's usually willing to adjust my shifts if possible. That flexibility is important to me because it helps me balance everything else I'm trying to juggle. I also like that I can choose to work extra hours on weekends if I need to, especially during busy seasons. It's not the most flexible job in the world, but it's enough to give me a sense of control over my time, which I think is one of the reasons I've been able to keep going with my volunteering and online courses. I know some people have more unpredictable schedules, but for me, this predictability helps me feel more grounded and in charge of my own path.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Angel Gonzalez: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, even if it's not ideal. I know we're not rolling in money, but I also know that we're not struggling in a way that makes life impossible. My parents have always been careful with what we have, and I've been learning from them how to budget, save, and prioritize what's important. I think the biggest challenge is knowing that I want more for myself—like being able to go to college full-time or pursuing a career in community development—but I also know that I have to take things step by step. I'm not in a rush, and I don't want to take on debt just to try to keep up with what others might consider 'success.' For now, I'm content with the stability we have, and I'm trying to use what I have to build a better future for myself and for the people I care about. I know it's not easy, but I also know that I'm not alone in this, and that gives me hope.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Angel Gonzalez: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked in construction, and he was always out on job sites, sometimes working long hours, especially during the summer months when there was more demand. He always said that hard work was the key to getting ahead, and I think that's why he never complained, even when the work was tough. My mom, on the other hand, was a stay-at-home mom for most of my childhood, but she did work part-time at a local daycare for a few years when I was younger. She told me that she wanted to be there for me and my sister, but she also wanted to contribute to the family in her own way. I remember her talking about how she missed her own friends and the freedom of working outside the home, but she always put our needs first. It wasn't easy for them, especially when money was tight, but they always made sure we had what we needed. I think that's why I value education and hard work so much—it's something they instilled in me from a young age, and I carry it with me even now as I try to figure out my own path.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Angel Gonzalez: My dad worked in construction, so his most important activities were managing job sites, overseeing crews, and making sure everything was done safely and on time. He was the kind of person who didn't just show up for the job—he showed up with a plan, a toolbelt, and a willingness to work through anything that came his way. I remember watching him fix things around the house, whether it was repairing a roof or reinforcing a wall, and it always amazed me how he could take something broken and make it whole again. My mom, when she did work at the daycare, her most important duties were caring for the children, making sure they were safe, and helping them learn basic skills like counting, sharing, and following routines. She had a way of making every child feel seen and valued, even if they were just sitting quietly in a corner. I think that's why she was so good at it—she treated every child like they were her own, and that made a difference. Looking back, I realize now that their work wasn't just about earning money—it was about responsibility, care, and doing the right thing, even when it wasn't easy. Those are the lessons I carry with me today.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Angel Gonzalez: My dad worked for a local construction company that handled both residential and commercial projects. They were one of the bigger firms in the area, and my dad started as a laborer but worked his way up to a foreman over the years. He was responsible for making sure that every job site ran smoothly, from laying the foundation to finishing the last nail. He always said that construction was like building a puzzle—you had to know where each piece went and how it fit with the others. My mom worked at a small daycare center owned by a friend of the family. It wasn't a big business, just a few rooms in a converted house, but it was a place where kids could learn and grow in a safe, loving environment. She made sure that every child felt seen and heard, and she had a way of turning even the most difficult days into something positive. Looking back, I realize now that their work wasn't just about earning money—it was about responsibility, care, and doing the right thing, even when it wasn't easy. Those are the lessons I carry with me today.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Angel Gonzalez: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in this neighborhood, still connected to the people who've helped shape who I am. I hope I'm working in community development, maybe even running a program at the community center or something similar, helping others the way I've been helped. I don't know exactly what that will look like, but I want to be someone who makes a difference, even in small ways. I also hope I'm more financially stable, maybe with a full-time job or some kind of certification that allows me to do the work I want to do. I don't see myself moving far away from here, though. There's something about this place that feels like home, and I want to be part of its future. I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still surrounded by the people I care about—my family, my friends, and the neighbors who've become like family. I think that's the kind of life I want: one that's grounded, meaningful, and full of connection.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Angel Gonzalez: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's with my family, my friends, or the people in my neighborhood. I think a lot of my decisions, like choosing to volunteer at the community center or staying in this neighborhood, come from a desire to be part of something bigger than myself. I also value growth, not just in the big, obvious ways, but in the small, daily choices to keep learning, to keep showing up, and to keep trying even when things feel uncertain. I value the lessons my parents taught me about hard work and responsibility, and I value the support of people like Mrs. Delgado, Mr. Ramirez, and Jasmine, who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself. I think, at the end of the day, what I value most is the sense of purpose that comes from helping others and from knowing that I'm part of a community that cares about each other.

I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but now I see how important it is to lean on the people I trust, whether it's my family, my friends, or even the community around me. It's also been eye-opening to think about how my household manages money and what that means for my future. Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of self-discovery and reflection. It's amazing how much my life has been shaped by the people around me—my family, my friends, and the community I've grown up in. I never thought of myself as someone with a dramatic story, but when I look back, there were so many moments that mattered: the conversation with my dad that led me to take a gap year, the mentorship from Mr. Ramirez, the support from my sister Maria, and the small but meaningful connections I've made at the community center. I've learned that growth doesn't always come from grand moments, but from the steady, consistent choices we make every day. I've also come to appreciate the value of stability, of having a support system, and of finding purpose in the little things. I'm still figuring out where I'm headed, but I feel more grounded and more connected to who I want to become. This interview has reminded me that even if my life hasn't been filled with grand adventures, it's been built on steady foundations and meaningful relationships. I'm grateful for that, and I'm excited to see where this path takes me next.
